title: Dhammapada 1:1
body: All that we are is the result of what we have thought: it is founded on our thoughts, it is made up of our thoughts. If a man speaks or acts with an evil thought, pain follows him, as the wheel follows the foot of the ox that draws the carriage.

title: Dhammapada 1:2
body: All that we are is the result of what we have thought: it is founded on our thoughts, it is made up of our thoughts. If a man speaks or acts with a pure thought, happiness follows him, like a shadow that never leaves him.

title: Dhammapada 1:3
body: "He abused me, he beat me, he defeated me, he robbed me,"--in those who harbour such thoughts hatred will never cease.

title: Dhammapada 1:4
body: "He abused me, he beat me, he defeated me, he robbed me,"--in those who do not harbour such thoughts hatred will cease.

title: Dhammapada 1:5
body: For hatred does not cease by hatred at any time: hatred ceases by love, this is an old rule.

title: Dhammapada 1:6
body: The world does not know that we must all come to an end here;--but those who know it, their quarrels cease at once.

title: Dhammapada 1:7
body: He who lives looking for pleasures only, his senses uncontrolled, immoderate in his food, idle, and weak, Mara (the tempter) will certainly overthrow him, as the wind throws down a weak tree.

title: Dhammapada 1:9
body: He who wishes to put on the yellow dress without having cleansed himself from sin, who disregards temperance and truth, is unworthy of the yellow dress.

title: Dhammapada 1:10
body: But he who has cleansed himself from sin, is well grounded in all virtues, and regards also temperance and truth, he is indeed worthy of the yellow dress.

title: Dhammapada 1:11
body: They who imagine truth in untruth, and see untruth in truth, never arrive at truth, but follow vain desires.

title: Dhammapada 1:12
body: They who know truth in truth, and untruth in untruth, arrive at truth, and follow true desires.

title: Dhammapada 1:13
body: As rain breaks through an ill-thatched house, passion will break through an unreflecting mind.

title: Dhammapada 1:14
body: As rain does not break through a well-thatched house, passion will not break through a well-reflecting mind.

title: Dhammapada 1:16
body: The virtuous man delights in this world, and he delights in the next; he delights in both. He delights and rejoices, when he sees the purity of his own work.

title: Dhammapada 1:17
body: The evil-doer suffers in this world, and he suffers in the next; he suffers in both. He suffers when he thinks of the evil he has done; he suffers more when going on the evil path.

title: Dhammapada 1:18
body: The virtuous man is happy in this world, and he is happy in the next; he is happy in both. He is happy when he thinks of the good he has done; he is still more happy when going on the good path.

title: Dhammapada 1:19
body: The thoughtless man, even if he can recite a large portion (of the law), but is not a doer of it, has no share in the priesthood, but is like a cowherd counting the cows of others.

title: Dhammapada 1:20
body: The follower of the law, even if he can recite only a small portion (of the law), but, having forsaken passion and hatred and foolishness, possesses true knowledge and serenity of mind, he, caring for nothing in this world or that to come, has indeed a share in the priesthood. Chapter II. On Earnestness

title: Dhammapada 2:21
body: Earnestness is the path of immortality (Nirvana), thoughtlessness the path of death. Those who are in earnest do not die, those who are thoughtless are as if dead already.

title: Dhammapada 2:23
body: These wise people, meditative, steady, always possessed of strong powers, attain to Nirvana, the highest happiness.

title: Dhammapada 2:24
body: If an earnest person has roused himself, if he is not forgetful, if his deeds are pure, if he acts with consideration, if he restrains himself, and lives according to law,--then his glory will increase.

title: Dhammapada 2:25
body: By rousing himself, by earnestness, by restraint and control, the wise man may make for himself an island which no flood can overwhelm.

title: Dhammapada 2:26
body: Fools follow after vanity, men of evil wisdom. The wise man keeps earnestness as his best jewel.

title: Dhammapada 2:27
body: Follow not after vanity, nor after the enjoyment of love and lust! He who is earnest and meditative, obtains ample joy.

title: Dhammapada 2:28
body: When the learned man drives away vanity by earnestness, he, the wise, climbing the terraced heights of wisdom, looks down upon the fools, serene he looks upon the toiling crowd, as one that stands on a mountain looks down upon them that stand upon the plain.

title: Dhammapada 2:29
body: Earnest among the thoughtless, awake among the sleepers, the wise man advances like a racer, leaving behind the hack.

title: Dhammapada 2:31
body: A Bhikshu (mendicant) who delights in earnestness, who looks with fear on thoughtlessness, moves about like fire, burning all his fetters, small or large.

title: Dhammapada 2:32
body: A Bhikshu (mendicant) who delights in reflection, who looks with fear on thoughtlessness, cannot fall away (from his perfect state)--he is close upon Nirvana. Chapter III. Thought

title: Dhammapada 3:33
body: As a fletcher makes straight his arrow, a wise man makes straight his trembling and unsteady thought, which is difficult to guard, difficult to hold back.

title: Dhammapada 3:34
body: As a fish taken from his watery home and thrown on dry ground, our thought trembles all over in order to escape the dominion of Mara (the tempter).

title: Dhammapada 3:35
body: It is good to tame the mind, which is difficult to hold in and flighty, rushing wherever it listeth; a tamed mind brings happiness.

title: Dhammapada 3:36
body: Let the wise man guard his thoughts, for they are difficult to perceive, very artful, and they rush wherever they list: thoughts well guarded bring happiness.

title: Dhammapada 3:38
body: If a man's thoughts are unsteady, if he does not know the true law, if his peace of mind is troubled, his knowledge will never be perfect.

title: Dhammapada 3:39
body: If a man's thoughts are not dissipated, if his mind is not perplexed, if he has ceased to think of good or evil, then there is no fear for him while he is watchful.

title: Dhammapada 3:40
body: Knowing that this body is (fragile) like a jar, and making this thought firm like a fortress, one should attack Mara (the tempter) with the weapon of knowledge, one should watch him when conquered, and should never rest.

title: Dhammapada 3:41
body: Before long, alas! this body will lie on the earth, despised, without understanding, like a useless log.

title: Dhammapada 3:42
body: Whatever a hater may do to a hater, or an enemy to an enemy, a wrongly-directed mind will do us greater mischief.

title: Dhammapada 3:43
body: Not a mother, not a father will do so much, nor any other relative; a well-directed mind will do us greater service. Chapter IV. Flowers

title: Dhammapada 4:45
body: The disciple will overcome the earth, and the world of Yama, and the world of the gods. The disciple will find out the plainly shown path of virtue, as a clever man finds out the (right) flower.

title: Dhammapada 4:46
body: He who knows that this body is like froth, and has learnt that it is as unsubstantial as a mirage, will break the flower-pointed arrow of Mara, and never see the king of death.

title: Dhammapada 4:47
body: Death carries off a man who is gathering flowers and whose mind is distracted, as a flood carries off a sleeping village.

title: Dhammapada 4:48
body: Death subdues a man who is gathering flowers, and whose mind is distracted, before he is satiated in his pleasures.

title: Dhammapada 4:49
body: As the bee collects nectar and departs without injuring the flower, or its colour or scent, so let a sage dwell in his village.

title: Dhammapada 4:50
body: Not the perversities of others, not their sins of commission or omission, but his own misdeeds and negligences should a sage take notice of.

title: Dhammapada 4:51
body: Like a beautiful flower, full of colour, but without scent, are the fine but fruitless words of him who does not act accordingly.

title: Dhammapada 4:53
body: As many kinds of wreaths can be made from a heap of flowers, so many good things may be achieved by a mortal when once he is born.

title: Dhammapada 4:54
body: The scent of flowers does not travel against the wind, nor (that of) sandal-wood, or of Tagara and Mallika flowers; but the odour of good people travels even against the wind; a good man pervades every place.

title: Dhammapada 4:55
body: Sandal-wood or Tagara, a lotus-flower, or a Vassiki, among these sorts of perfumes, the perfume of virtue is unsurpassed.

title: Dhammapada 4:56
body: Mean is the scent that comes from Tagara and sandal-wood;--the perfume of those who possess virtue rises up to the gods as the highest.

title: Dhammapada 4:57
body: Of the people who possess these virtues, who live without thoughtlessness, and who are emancipated through true knowledge, Mara, the tempter, never finds the way. 58, 59. As on a heap of rubbish cast upon the highway the lily will grow full of sweet perfume and delight, thus the disciple of the truly enlightened Buddha shines forth by his knowledge among those who are like rubbish, among the people that walk in darkness. Chapter V. The Fool

title: Dhammapada 4:58
body: [Verse not found]

title: Dhammapada 5:60
body: Long is the night to him who is awake; long is a mile to him who is tired; long is life to the foolish who do not know the true law.

title: Dhammapada 5:61
body: If a traveller does not meet with one who is his better, or his equal, let him firmly keep to his solitary journey; there is no companionship with a fool.

title: Dhammapada 5:62
body: "These sons belong to me, and this wealth belongs to me," with such thoughts a fool is tormented. He himself does not belong to himself; how much less sons and wealth?

title: Dhammapada 5:63
body: The fool who knows his foolishness, is wise at least so far. But a fool who thinks himself wise, he is called a fool indeed.

title: Dhammapada 5:64
body: If a fool be associated with a wise man even all his life, he will perceive the truth as little as a spoon perceives the taste of soup.

title: Dhammapada 5:65
body: If an intelligent man be associated for one minute only with a wise man, he will soon perceive the truth, as the tongue perceives the taste of soup.

title: Dhammapada 5:67
body: That deed is not well done of which a man must repent, and the reward of which he receives crying and with a tearful face.

title: Dhammapada 5:68
body: No, that deed is well done of which a man does not repent, and the reward of which he receives gladly and cheerfully.

title: Dhammapada 5:69
body: As long as the evil deed done does not bear fruit, the fool thinks it is like honey; but when it ripens, then the fool suffers grief.

title: Dhammapada 5:70
body: Let a fool month after month eat his food (like an ascetic) with the tip of a blade of Kusa grass, yet he is not worth the sixteenth particle of those who have well weighed the law.

title: Dhammapada 5:71
body: An evil deed, like newly-drawn milk, does not turn (suddenly); smouldering, like fire covered by ashes, it follows the fool.

title: Dhammapada 5:72
body: And when the evil deed, after it has become known, brings sorrow to the fool, then it destroys his bright lot, nay, it cleaves his head.

title: Dhammapada 5:74
body: "May both the layman and he who has left the world think that this is done by me; may they be subject to me in everything which is to be done or is not to be done," thus is the mind of the fool, and his desire and pride increase.

title: Dhammapada 5:75
body: "One is the road that leads to wealth, another the road that leads to Nirvana;" if the Bhikshu, the disciple of Buddha, has learnt this, he will not yearn for honour, he will strive after separation from the world. Chapter VI. The Wise Man (Pandita)

title: Dhammapada 6:76
body: If you see an intelligent man who tells you where true treasures are to be found, who shows what is to be avoided, and administers reproofs, follow that wise man; it will be better, not worse, for those who follow him.

title: Dhammapada 6:77
body: Let him admonish, let him teach, let him forbid what is improper!--he will be beloved of the good, by the bad he will be hated.

title: Dhammapada 6:78
body: Do not have evil-doers for friends, do not have low people for friends: have virtuous people for friends, have for friends the best of men.

title: Dhammapada 6:79
body: He who drinks in the law lives happily with a serene mind: the sage rejoices always in the law, as preached by the elect (Ariyas).

title: Dhammapada 6:80
body: Well-makers lead the water (wherever they like); fletchers bend the arrow; carpenters bend a log of wood; wise people fashion themselves.

title: Dhammapada 6:82
body: Wise people, after they have listened to the laws, become serene, like a deep, smooth, and still lake.

title: Dhammapada 6:83
body: Good people walk on whatever befall, the good do not prattle, longing for pleasure; whether touched by happiness or sorrow wise people never appear elated or depressed.

title: Dhammapada 6:84
body: If, whether for his own sake, or for the sake of others, a man wishes neither for a son, nor for wealth, nor for lordship, and if he does not wish for his own success by unfair means, then he is good, wise, and virtuous.

title: Dhammapada 6:85
body: Few are there among men who arrive at the other shore (become Arhats); the other people here run up and down the shore.

title: Dhammapada 6:86
body: But those who, when the law has been well preached to them, follow the law, will pass across the dominion of death, however difficult to overcome. 87, 88. A wise man should leave the dark state (of ordinary life), and follow the bright state (of the Bhikshu). After going from his home to a homeless state, he should in his retirement look for enjoyment where there seemed to be no enjoyment. Leaving all pleasures behind, and calling nothing his own, the wise man should purge himself from all the troubles of the mind.

title: Dhammapada 6:87
body: [Verse not found]

title: Dhammapada 6:89
body: Those whose mind is well grounded in the (seven) elements of knowledge, who without clinging to anything, rejoice in freedom from attachment, whose appetites have been conquered, and who are full of light, are free (even) in this world. Chapter VII. The Venerable (Arhat).

title: Dhammapada 7:90
body: There is no suffering for him who has finished his journey, and abandoned grief, who has freed himself on all sides, and thrown off all fetters.

title: Dhammapada 7:91
body: They depart with their thoughts well-collected, they are not happy in their abode; like swans who have left their lake, they leave their house and home.

title: Dhammapada 7:92
body: Men who have no riches, who live on recognised food, who have perceived void and unconditioned freedom (Nirvana), their path is difficult to understand, like that of birds in the air.

title: Dhammapada 7:93
body: He whose appetites are stilled, who is not absorbed in enjoyment, who has perceived void and unconditioned freedom (Nirvana), his path is difficult to understand, like that of birds in the air.

title: Dhammapada 7:94
body: The gods even envy him whose senses, like horses well broken in by the driver, have been subdued, who is free from pride, and free from appetites.

title: Dhammapada 7:96
body: His thought is quiet, quiet are his word and deed, when he has obtained freedom by true knowledge, when he has thus become a quiet man.

title: Dhammapada 7:97
body: The man who is free from credulity, but knows the uncreated, who has cut all ties, removed all temptations, renounced all desires, he is the greatest of men.

title: Dhammapada 7:98
body: In a hamlet or in a forest, in the deep water or on the dry land, wherever venerable persons (Arhanta) dwell, that place is delightful.

title: Dhammapada 7:99
body: Forests are delightful; where the world finds no delight, there the passionless will find delight, for they look not for pleasures. Chapter VIII. The Thousands

title: Dhammapada 8:100
body: Even though a speech be a thousand (of words), but made up of senseless words, one word of sense is better, which if a man hears, he becomes quiet.

title: Dhammapada 8:101
body: Even though a Gatha (poem) be a thousand (of words), but made up of senseless words, one word of a Gatha is better, which if a man hears, he becomes quiet.

title: Dhammapada 8:102
body: Though a man recite a hundred Gathas made up of senseless words, one word of the law is better, which if a man hears, he becomes quiet.

title: Dhammapada 8:104
body: [Verse not found]

title: Dhammapada 8:105
body: [Verse not found]

title: Dhammapada 8:106
body: If a man for a hundred years sacrifice month after month with a thousand, and if he but for one moment pay homage to a man whose soul is grounded (in true knowledge), better is that homage than sacrifice for a hundred years.

title: Dhammapada 8:107
body: If a man for a hundred years worship Agni (fire) in the forest, and if he but for one moment pay homage to a man whose soul is grounded (in true knowledge), better is that homage than sacrifice for a hundred years.

title: Dhammapada 8:108
body: Whatever a man sacrifice in this world as an offering or as an oblation for a whole year in order to gain merit, the whole of it is not worth a quarter (a farthing); reverence shown to the righteous is better.

title: Dhammapada 8:109
body: He who always greets and constantly reveres the aged, four things will increase to him, viz. life, beauty, happiness, power.

title: Dhammapada 8:111
body: And he who lives a hundred years, ignorant and unrestrained, a life of one day is better if a man is wise and reflecting.

title: Dhammapada 8:112
body: And he who lives a hundred years, idle and weak, a life of one day is better if a man has attained firm strength.

title: Dhammapada 8:113
body: And he who lives a hundred years, not seeing beginning and end, a life of one day is better if a man sees beginning and end.

title: Dhammapada 8:114
body: And he who lives a hundred years, not seeing the immortal place, a life of one day is better if a man sees the immortal place.

title: Dhammapada 8:115
body: And he who lives a hundred years, not seeing the highest law, a life of one day is better if a man sees the highest law. Chapter IX. Evil

title: Dhammapada 9:116
body: If a man would hasten towards the good, he should keep his thought away from evil; if a man does what is good slothfully, his mind delights in evil.

title: Dhammapada 9:118
body: If a man does what is good, let him do it again; let him delight in it: happiness is the outcome of good.

title: Dhammapada 9:119
body: Even an evil-doer sees happiness as long as his evil deed has not ripened; but when his evil deed has ripened, then does the evil-doer see evil.

title: Dhammapada 9:120
body: Even a good man sees evil days, as long as his good deed has not ripened; but when his good deed has ripened, then does the good man see happy days.

title: Dhammapada 9:121
body: Let no man think lightly of evil, saying in his heart, It will not come nigh unto me. Even by the falling of water-drops a water-pot is filled; the fool becomes full of evil, even if he gather it little by little.

title: Dhammapada 9:122
body: Let no man think lightly of good, saying in his heart, It will not come nigh unto me. Even by the falling of water-drops a water-pot is filled; the wise man becomes full of good, even if he gather it little by little.

title: Dhammapada 9:123
body: Let a man avoid evil deeds, as a merchant, if he has few companions and carries much wealth, avoids a dangerous road; as a man who loves life avoids poison.

title: Dhammapada 9:125
body: If a man offend a harmless, pure, and innocent person, the evil falls back upon that fool, like light dust thrown up against the wind.

title: Dhammapada 9:126
body: Some people are born again; evil-doers go to hell; righteous people go to heaven; those who are free from all worldly desires attain Nirvana.

title: Dhammapada 9:127
body: Not in the sky, not in the midst of the sea, not if we enter into the clefts of the mountains, is there known a spot in the whole world where a man might be freed from an evil deed.

title: Dhammapada 9:128
body: Not in the sky, not in the midst of the sea, not if we enter into the clefts of the mountains, is there known a spot in the whole world where death could not overcome (the mortal). Chapter X. Punishment

title: Dhammapada 10:129
body: All men tremble at punishment, all men fear death; remember that you are like unto them, and do not kill, nor cause slaughter.

title: Dhammapada 10:130
body: All men tremble at punishment, all men love life; remember that thou art like unto them, and do not kill, nor cause slaughter.

title: Dhammapada 10:131
body: He who seeking his own happiness punishes or kills beings who also long for happiness, will not find happiness after death.

title: Dhammapada 10:133
body: Do not speak harshly to anybody; those who are spoken to will answer thee in the same way. Angry speech is painful, blows for blows will touch thee.

title: Dhammapada 10:134
body: If, like a shattered metal plate (gong), thou utter not, then thou hast reached Nirvana; contention is not known to thee.

title: Dhammapada 10:135
body: As a cowherd with his staff drives his cows into the stable, so do Age and Death drive the life of men.

title: Dhammapada 10:136
body: A fool does not know when he commits his evil deeds: but the wicked man burns by his own deeds, as if burnt by fire.

title: Dhammapada 10:137
body: He who inflicts pain on innocent and harmless persons, will soon come to one of these ten states:

title: Dhammapada 10:138
body: He will have cruel suffering, loss, injury of the body, heavy affliction, or loss of mind,

title: Dhammapada 10:140
body: Or lightning-fire will burn his houses; and when his body is destroyed, the fool will go to hell.

title: Dhammapada 10:141
body: Not nakedness, not platted hair, not dirt, not fasting, or lying on the earth, not rubbing with dust, not sitting motionless, can purify a mortal who has not overcome desires.

title: Dhammapada 10:142
body: He who, though dressed in fine apparel, exercises tranquillity, is quiet, subdued, restrained, chaste, and has ceased to find fault with all other beings, he indeed is a Brahmana, an ascetic (sramana), a friar (bhikshu).

title: Dhammapada 10:143
body: Is there in this world any man so restrained by humility that he does not mind reproof, as a well-trained horse the whip?

title: Dhammapada 10:144
body: Like a well-trained horse when touched by the whip, be ye active and lively, and by faith, by virtue, by energy, by meditation, by discernment of the law you will overcome this great pain (of reproof), perfect in knowledge and in behaviour, and never forgetful.

title: Dhammapada 10:145
body: Well-makers lead the water (wherever they like); fletchers bend the arrow; carpenters bend a log of wood; good people fashion themselves. Chapter XI. Old Age

title: Dhammapada 11:147
body: Look at this dressed-up lump, covered with wounds, joined together, sickly, full of many thoughts, which has no strength, no hold!

title: Dhammapada 11:148
body: This body is wasted, full of sickness, and frail; this heap of corruption breaks to pieces, life indeed ends in death.

title: Dhammapada 11:149
body: Those white bones, like gourds thrown away in the autumn, what pleasure is there in looking at them?

title: Dhammapada 11:150
body: After a stronghold has been made of the bones, it is covered with flesh and blood, and there dwell in it old age and death, pride and deceit.

title: Dhammapada 11:151
body: The brilliant chariots of kings are destroyed, the body also approaches destruction, but the virtue of good people never approaches destruction,--thus do the good say to the good.

title: Dhammapada 11:152
body: A man who has learnt little, grows old like an ox; his flesh grows, but his knowledge does not grow. 153, 154. Looking for the maker of this tabernacle, I shall have to run through a course of many births, so long as I do not find (him); and painful is birth again and again. But now, maker of the tabernacle, thou hast been seen; thou shalt not make up this tabernacle again. All thy rafters are broken, thy ridge-pole is sundered; the mind, approaching the Eternal (visankhara, nirvana), has attained to the extinction of all desires.

title: Dhammapada 11:153
body: [Verse not found]

title: Dhammapada 11:155
body: Men who have not observed proper discipline, and have not gained treasure in their youth, perish like old herons in a lake without fish.

title: Dhammapada 11:156
body: Men who have not observed proper discipline, and have not gained treasure in their youth, lie, like broken bows, sighing after the past. Chapter XII. Self

title: Dhammapada 12:157
body: If a man hold himself dear, let him watch himself carefully; during one at least out of the three watches a wise man should be watchful.

title: Dhammapada 12:158
body: Let each man direct himself first to what is proper, then let him teach others; thus a wise man will not suffer.

title: Dhammapada 12:159
body: If a man make himself as he teaches others to be, then, being himself well subdued, he may subdue (others); one's own self is indeed difficult to subdue.

title: Dhammapada 12:160
body: Self is the lord of self, who else could be the lord? With self well subdued, a man finds a lord such as few can find.

title: Dhammapada 12:162
body: He whose wickedness is very great brings himself down to that state where his enemy wishes him to be, as a creeper does with the tree which it surrounds.

title: Dhammapada 12:163
body: Bad deeds, and deeds hurtful to ourselves, are easy to do; what is beneficial and good, that is very difficult to do.

title: Dhammapada 12:164
body: The foolish man who scorns the rule of the venerable (Arahat), of the elect (Ariya), of the virtuous, and follows false doctrine, he bears fruit to his own destruction, like the fruits of the Katthaka reed.

title: Dhammapada 12:165
body: By oneself the evil is done, by oneself one suffers; by oneself evil is left undone, by oneself one is purified. Purity and impurity belong to oneself, no one can purify another.

title: Dhammapada 12:166
body: Let no one forget his own duty for the sake of another's, however great; let a man, after he has discerned his own duty, be always attentive to his duty. Chapter XIII. The World

title: Dhammapada 13:167
body: Do not follow the evil law! Do not live on in thoughtlessness! Do not follow false doctrine! Be not a friend of the world.

title: Dhammapada 13:169
body: Follow the law of virtue; do not follow that of sin. The virtuous rests in bliss in this world and in the next.

title: Dhammapada 13:170
body: Look upon the world as a bubble, look upon it as a mirage: the king of death does not see him who thus looks down upon the world.

title: Dhammapada 13:171
body: Come, look at this glittering world, like unto a royal chariot; the foolish are immersed in it, but the wise do not touch it.

title: Dhammapada 13:172
body: He who formerly was reckless and afterwards became sober, brightens up this world, like the moon when freed from clouds.

title: Dhammapada 13:173
body: He whose evil deeds are covered by good deeds, brightens up this world, like the moon when freed from clouds.

title: Dhammapada 13:174
body: This world is dark, few only can see here; a few only go to heaven, like birds escaped from the net.

title: Dhammapada 13:175
body: The swans go on the path of the sun, they go through the ether by means of their miraculous power; the wise are led out of this world, when they have conquered Mara and his train.

title: Dhammapada 13:177
body: The uncharitable do not go to the world of the gods; fools only do not praise liberality; a wise man rejoices in liberality, and through it becomes blessed in the other world.

title: Dhammapada 13:178
body: Better than sovereignty over the earth, better than going to heaven, better than lordship over all worlds, is the reward of the first step in holiness. Chapter XIV. The Buddha (The Awakened)

title: Dhammapada 14:179
body: He whose conquest is not conquered again, into whose conquest no one in this world enters, by what track can you lead him, the Awakened, the Omniscient, the trackless?

title: Dhammapada 14:180
body: He whom no desire with its snares and poisons can lead astray, by what track can you lead him, the Awakened, the Omniscient, the trackless?

title: Dhammapada 14:181
body: Even the gods envy those who are awakened and not forgetful, who are given to meditation, who are wise, and who delight in the repose of retirement (from the world).

title: Dhammapada 14:182
body: Difficult (to obtain) is the conception of men, difficult is the life of mortals, difficult is the hearing of the True Law, difficult is the birth of the Awakened (the attainment of Buddhahood).

title: Dhammapada 14:184
body: The Awakened call patience the highest penance, long-suffering the highest Nirvana; for he is not an anchorite (pravragita) who strikes others, he is not an ascetic (sramana) who insults others.

title: Dhammapada 14:185
body: Not to blame, not to strike, to live restrained under the law, to be moderate in eating, to sleep and sit alone, and to dwell on the highest thoughts,--this is the teaching of the Awakened.

title: Dhammapada 14:186
body: There is no satisfying lusts, even by a shower of gold pieces; he who knows that lusts have a short taste and cause pain, he is wise;

title: Dhammapada 14:187
body: Even in heavenly pleasures he finds no satisfaction, the disciple who is fully awakened delights only in the destruction of all desires.

title: Dhammapada 14:188
body: Men, driven by fear, go to many a refuge, to mountains and forests, to groves and sacred trees.

title: Dhammapada 14:189
body: But that is not a safe refuge, that is not the best refuge; a man is not delivered from all pains after having gone to that refuge.

title: Dhammapada 14:191
body: Viz. pain, the origin of pain, the destruction of pain, and the eightfold holy way that leads to the quieting of pain;--

title: Dhammapada 14:192
body: That is the safe refuge, that is the best refuge; having gone to that refuge, a man is delivered from all pain.

title: Dhammapada 14:193
body: A supernatural person (a Buddha) is not easily found, he is not born everywhere. Wherever such a sage is born, that race prospers.

title: Dhammapada 14:194
body: Happy is the arising of the awakened, happy is the teaching of the True Law, happy is peace in the church, happy is the devotion of those who are at peace. 195, 196. He who pays homage to those who deserve homage, whether the awakened (Buddha) or their disciples, those who have overcome the host (of evils), and crossed the flood of sorrow, he who pays homage to such as have found deliverance and know no fear, his merit can never be measured by anybody. Chapter XV. Happiness

title: Dhammapada 14:195
body: [Verse not found]

title: Dhammapada 14:196
body: [Verse not found]

title: Dhammapada 15:198
body: Let us live happily then, free from ailments among the ailing! among men who are ailing let us dwell free from ailments!

title: Dhammapada 15:199
body: Let us live happily then, free from greed among the greedy! among men who are greedy let us dwell free from greed!

title: Dhammapada 15:200
body: Let us live happily then, though we call nothing our own! We shall be like the bright gods, feeding on happiness!

title: Dhammapada 15:201
body: Victory breeds hatred, for the conquered is unhappy. He who has given up both victory and defeat, he, the contented, is happy.

title: Dhammapada 15:202
body: There is no fire like passion; there is no losing throw like hatred; there is no pain like this body; there is no happiness higher than rest.

title: Dhammapada 15:203
body: Hunger is the worst of diseases, the body the greatest of pains; if one knows this truly, that is Nirvana, the highest happiness.

title: Dhammapada 15:204
body: Health is the greatest of gifts, contentedness the best riches; trust is the best of relationships, Nirvana the highest happiness.

title: Dhammapada 15:206
body: The sight of the elect (Arya) is good, to live with them is always happiness; if a man does not see fools, he will be truly happy.

title: Dhammapada 15:207
body: He who walks in the company of fools suffers a long way; company with fools, as with an enemy, is always painful; company with the wise is pleasure, like meeting with kinsfolk.

title: Dhammapada 15:208
body: Therefore, one ought to follow the wise, the intelligent, the learned, the much enduring, the dutiful, the elect; one ought to follow a good and wise man, as the moon follows the path of the stars. Chapter XVI. Pleasure

title: Dhammapada 16:209
body: He who gives himself to vanity, and does not give himself to meditation, forgetting the real aim (of life) and grasping at pleasure, will in time envy him who has exerted himself in meditation.

title: Dhammapada 16:210
body: Let no man ever look for what is pleasant, or what is unpleasant. Not to see what is pleasant is pain, and it is pain to see what is unpleasant.

title: Dhammapada 16:211
body: Let, therefore, no man love anything; loss of the beloved is evil. Those who love nothing and hate nothing, have no fetters.

title: Dhammapada 16:213
body: From affection comes grief, from affection comes fear; he who is free from affection knows neither grief nor fear.

title: Dhammapada 16:214
body: From lust comes grief, from lust comes fear; he who is free from lust knows neither grief nor fear.

title: Dhammapada 16:215
body: From love comes grief, from love comes fear; he who is free from love knows neither grief nor fear.

title: Dhammapada 16:216
body: From greed comes grief, from greed comes fear; he who is free from greed knows neither grief nor fear.

title: Dhammapada 16:217
body: He who possesses virtue and intelligence, who is just, speaks the truth, and does what is his own business, him the world will hold dear.

title: Dhammapada 16:218
body: He in whom a desire for the Ineffable (Nirvana) has sprung up, who is satisfied in his mind, and whose thoughts are not bewildered by love, he is called urdhvamsrotas (carried upwards by the stream).

title: Dhammapada 16:220
body: In like manner his good works receive him who has done good, and has gone from this world to the other;--as kinsmen receive a friend on his return. Chapter XVII. Anger

title: Dhammapada 17:221
body: Let a man leave anger, let him forsake pride, let him overcome all bondage! No sufferings befall the man who is not attached to name and form, and who calls nothing his own.

title: Dhammapada 17:222
body: He who holds back rising anger like a rolling chariot, him I call a real driver; other people are but holding the reins.

title: Dhammapada 17:223
body: Let a man overcome anger by love, let him overcome evil by good; let him overcome the greedy by liberality, the liar by truth!

title: Dhammapada 17:224
body: Speak the truth, do not yield to anger; give, if thou art asked for little; by these three steps thou wilt go near the gods.

title: Dhammapada 17:225
body: The sages who injure nobody, and who always control their body, they will go to the unchangeable place (Nirvana), where, if they have gone, they will suffer no more.

title: Dhammapada 17:226
body: Those who are ever watchful, who study day and night, and who strive after Nirvana, their passions will come to an end.

title: Dhammapada 17:228
body: There never was, there never will be, nor is there now, a man who is always blamed, or a man who is always praised. 229, 230. But he whom those who discriminate praise continually day after day, as without blemish, wise, rich in knowledge and virtue, who would dare to blame him, like a coin made of gold from the Gambu river? Even the gods praise him, he is praised even by Brahman.

title: Dhammapada 17:229
body: [Verse not found]

title: Dhammapada 17:230
body: [Verse not found]

title: Dhammapada 17:231
body: Beware of bodily anger, and control thy body! Leave the sins of the body, and with thy body practise virtue!

title: Dhammapada 17:232
body: Beware of the anger of the tongue, and control thy tongue! Leave the sins of the tongue, and practise virtue with thy tongue!

title: Dhammapada 17:233
body: Beware of the anger of the mind, and control thy mind! Leave the sins of the mind, and practise virtue with thy mind!

title: Dhammapada 18:235
body: Thou art now like a sear leaf, the messengers of death (Yama) have come near to thee; thou standest at the door of thy departure, and thou hast no provision for thy journey.

title: Dhammapada 18:236
body: Make thyself an island, work hard, be wise! When thy impurities are blown away, and thou art free from guilt, thou wilt enter into the heavenly world of the elect (Ariya).

title: Dhammapada 18:237
body: Thy life has come to an end, thou art come near to death (Yama), there is no resting-place for thee on the road, and thou hast no provision for thy journey.

title: Dhammapada 18:238
body: Make thyself an island, work hard, be wise! When thy impurities are blown away, and thou art free from guilt, thou wilt not enter again into birth and decay.

title: Dhammapada 18:239
body: Let a wise man blow off the impurities of his self, as a smith blows off the impurities of silver one by one, little by little, and from time to time.

title: Dhammapada 18:240
body: As the impurity which springs from the iron, when it springs from it, destroys it; thus do a transgressor's own works lead him to the evil path.

title: Dhammapada 18:242
body: Bad conduct is the taint of woman, greediness the taint of a benefactor; tainted are all evil ways in this world and in the next.

title: Dhammapada 18:243
body: But there is a taint worse than all taints,--ignorance is the greatest taint. O mendicants! throw off that taint, and become taintless!

title: Dhammapada 18:244
body: Life is easy to live for a man who is without shame, a crow hero, a mischief-maker, an insulting, bold, and wretched fellow.

title: Dhammapada 18:245
body: But life is hard to live for a modest man, who always looks for what is pure, who is disinterested, quiet, spotless, and intelligent.

title: Dhammapada 18:246
body: He who destroys life, who speaks untruth, who in this world takes what is not given him, who goes to another man's wife;

title: Dhammapada 18:247
body: And the man who gives himself to drinking intoxicating liquors, he, even in this world, digs up his own root.

title: Dhammapada 18:249
body: The world gives according to their faith or according to their pleasure: if a man frets about the food and the drink given to others, he will find no rest either by day or by night.

title: Dhammapada 18:250
body: He in whom that feeling is destroyed, and taken out with the very root, finds rest by day and by night.

title: Dhammapada 18:251
body: There is no fire like passion, there is no shark like hatred, there is no snare like folly, there is no torrent like greed.

title: Dhammapada 18:252
body: The fault of others is easily perceived, but that of oneself is difficult to perceive; a man winnows his neighbour's faults like chaff, but his own fault he hides, as a cheat hides the bad die from the gambler.

title: Dhammapada 18:253
body: If a man looks after the faults of others, and is always inclined to be offended, his own passions will grow, and he is far from the destruction of passions.

title: Dhammapada 18:254
body: There is no path through the air, a man is not a Samana by outward acts. The world delights in vanity, the Tathagatas (the Buddhas) are free from vanity.

title: Dhammapada 18:255
body: There is no path through the air, a man is not a Samana by outward acts. No creatures are eternal; but the awakened (Buddha) are never shaken. Chapter XIX. The Just 256, 257. A man is not just if he carries a matter by violence; no, he who distinguishes both right and wrong, who is learned and leads others, not by violence, but by law and equity, and who is guarded by the law and intelligent, he is called just.

title: Dhammapada 19:257
body: [Verse not found]

title: Dhammapada 19:258
body: A man is not learned because he talks much; he who is patient, free from hatred and fear, he is called learned.

title: Dhammapada 19:259
body: A man is not a supporter of the law because he talks much; even if a man has learnt little, but sees the law bodily, he is a supporter of the law, a man who never neglects the law.

title: Dhammapada 19:260
body: A man is not an elder because his head is grey; his age may be ripe, but he is called `Old-in-vain.'

title: Dhammapada 19:261
body: He in whom there is truth, virtue, love, restraint, moderation, he who is free from impurity and is wise, he is called an elder.

title: Dhammapada 19:262
body: An envious greedy, dishonest man does not become respectable by means of much talking only, or by the beauty of his complexion.

title: Dhammapada 19:264
body: Not by tonsure does an undisciplined man who speaks falsehood become a Samana; can a man be a Samana who is still held captive by desire and greediness?

title: Dhammapada 19:265
body: He who always quiets the evil, whether small or large, he is called a Samana (a quiet man), because he has quieted all evil.

title: Dhammapada 19:266
body: A man is not a mendicant (Bhikshu) simply because he asks others for alms; he who adopts the whole law is a Bhikshu, not he who only begs.

title: Dhammapada 19:267
body: He who is above good and evil, who is chaste, who with knowledge passes through the world, he indeed is called a Bhikshu. 268, 269. A man is not a Muni because he observes silence (mona, i.e. mauna), if he is foolish and ignorant; but the wise who, taking the balance, chooses the good and avoids evil, he is a Muni, and is a Muni thereby; he who in this world weighs both sides is called a Muni.

title: Dhammapada 19:268
body: [Verse not found]

title: Dhammapada 19:269
body: [Verse not found]

title: Dhammapada 19:271
body: [Verse not found]

title: Dhammapada 19:272
body: [Verse not found]

title: Dhammapada 20:273
body: The best of ways is the eightfold; the best of truths the four words; the best of virtues passionlessness; the best of men he who has eyes to see.

title: Dhammapada 20:274
body: This is the way, there is no other that leads to the purifying of intelligence. Go on this way! Everything else is the deceit of Mara (the tempter).

title: Dhammapada 20:275
body: If you go on this way, you will make an end of pain! The way was preached by me, when I had understood the removal of the thorns (in the flesh).

title: Dhammapada 20:276
body: You yourself must make an effort. The Tathagatas (Buddhas) are only preachers. The thoughtful who enter the way are freed from the bondage of Mara.

title: Dhammapada 20:277
body: `All created things perish,' he who knows and sees this becomes passive in pain; this is the way to purity.

title: Dhammapada 20:279
body: `All forms are unreal,' he who knows and sees this becomes passive in pain; this is the way that leads to purity.

title: Dhammapada 20:280
body: He who does not rouse himself when it is time to rise, who, though young and strong, is full of sloth, whose will and thought are weak, that lazy and idle man will never find the way to knowledge.

title: Dhammapada 20:281
body: Watching his speech, well restrained in mind, let a man never commit any wrong with his body! Let a man but keep these three roads of action clear, and he will achieve the way which is taught by the wise.

title: Dhammapada 20:282
body: Through zeal knowledge is gotten, through lack of zeal knowledge is lost; let a man who knows this double path of gain and loss thus place himself that knowledge may grow.

title: Dhammapada 20:283
body: Cut down the whole forest (of lust), not a tree only! Danger comes out of the forest (of lust). When you have cut down both the forest (of lust) and its undergrowth, then, Bhikshus, you will be rid of the forest and free!

title: Dhammapada 20:284
body: So long as the love of man towards women, even the smallest, is not destroyed, so long is his mind in bondage, as the calf that drinks milk is to its mother.

title: Dhammapada 20:286
body: `Here I shall dwell in the rain, here in winter and summer,' thus the fool meditates, and does not think of his death.

title: Dhammapada 20:287
body: Death comes and carries off that man, praised for his children and flocks, his mind distracted, as a flood carries off a sleeping village.

title: Dhammapada 20:288
body: Sons are no help, nor a father, nor relations; there is no help from kinsfolk for one whom death has seized.

title: Dhammapada 20:289
body: A wise and good man who knows the meaning of this, should quickly clear the way that leads to Nirvana. Chapter XXI. Miscellaneous

title: Dhammapada 21:290
body: If by leaving a small pleasure one sees a great pleasure, let a wise man leave the small pleasure, and look to the great.

title: Dhammapada 21:291
body: He who, by causing pain to others, wishes to obtain pleasure for himself, he, entangled in the bonds of hatred, will never be free from hatred.

title: Dhammapada 21:293
body: But they whose whole watchfulness is always directed to their body, who do not follow what ought not to be done, and who steadfastly do what ought to be done, the desires of such watchful and wise people will come to an end.

title: Dhammapada 21:294
body: A true Brahmana goes scatheless, though he have killed father and mother, and two valiant kings, though he has destroyed a kingdom with all its subjects.

title: Dhammapada 21:295
body: A true Brahmana goes scatheless, though he have killed father and mother, and two holy kings, and an eminent man besides.

title: Dhammapada 21:296
body: The disciples of Gotama (Buddha) are always well awake, and their thoughts day and night are always set on Buddha.

title: Dhammapada 21:297
body: The disciples of Gotama are always well awake, and their thoughts day and night are always set on the law.

title: Dhammapada 21:298
body: The disciples of Gotama are always well awake, and their thoughts day and night are always set on the church.

title: Dhammapada 21:299
body: The disciples of Gotama are always well awake, and their thoughts day and night are always set on their body.

title: Dhammapada 21:301
body: The disciples of Gotama are always well awake, and their mind day and night always delights in meditation.

title: Dhammapada 21:302
body: It is hard to leave the world (to become a friar), it is hard to enjoy the world; hard is the monastery, painful are the houses; painful it is to dwell with equals (to share everything in common) and the itinerant mendicant is beset with pain. Therefore let no man be an itinerant mendicant and he will not be beset with pain.

title: Dhammapada 21:303
body: Whatever place a faithful, virtuous, celebrated, and wealthy man chooses, there he is respected.

title: Dhammapada 21:304
body: Good people shine from afar, like the snowy mountains; bad people are not seen, like arrows shot by night.

title: Dhammapada 21:305
body: He alone who, without ceasing, practises the duty of sitting alone and sleeping alone, he, subduing himself, will rejoice in the destruction of all desires alone, as if living in a forest. Chapter XXII. The Downward Course

title: Dhammapada 22:306
body: He who says what is not, goes to hell; he also who, having done a thing, says I have not done it. After death both are equal, they are men with evil deeds in the next world.

title: Dhammapada 22:308
body: Better it would be to swallow a heated iron ball, like flaring fire, than that a bad unrestrained fellow should live on the charity of the land.

title: Dhammapada 22:309
body: Four things does a wreckless man gain who covets his neighbour's wife,--a bad reputation, an uncomfortable bed, thirdly, punishment, and lastly, hell.

title: Dhammapada 22:310
body: There is bad reputation, and the evil way (to hell), there is the short pleasure of the frightened in the arms of the frightened, and the king imposes heavy punishment; therefore let no man think of his neighbour's wife.

title: Dhammapada 22:311
body: As a grass-blade, if badly grasped, cuts the arm, badly-practised asceticism leads to hell.

title: Dhammapada 22:312
body: An act carelessly performed, a broken vow, and hesitating obedience to discipline, all this brings no great reward.

title: Dhammapada 22:313
body: If anything is to be done, let a man do it, let him attack it vigorously! A careless pilgrim only scatters the dust of his passions more widely.

title: Dhammapada 22:315
body: Like a well-guarded frontier fort, with defences within and without, so let a man guard himself. Not a moment should escape, for they who allow the right moment to pass, suffer pain when they are in hell.

title: Dhammapada 22:316
body: They who are ashamed of what they ought not to be ashamed of, and are not ashamed of what they ought to be ashamed of, such men, embracing false doctrines enter the evil path.

title: Dhammapada 22:317
body: They who fear when they ought not to fear, and fear not when they ought to fear, such men, embracing false doctrines, enter the evil path.

title: Dhammapada 22:318
body: They who forbid when there is nothing to be forbidden, and forbid not when there is something to be forbidden, such men, embracing false doctrines, enter the evil path.

title: Dhammapada 22:319
body: They who know what is forbidden as forbidden, and what is not forbidden as not forbidden, such men, embracing the true doctrine, enter the good path. Chapter XXIII. The Elephant

title: Dhammapada 23:320
body: Silently shall I endure abuse as the elephant in battle endures the arrow sent from the bow: for the world is ill-natured.

title: Dhammapada 23:322
body: Mules are good, if tamed, and noble Sindhu horses, and elephants with large tusks; but he who tames himself is better still.

title: Dhammapada 23:323
body: For with these animals does no man reach the untrodden country (Nirvana), where a tamed man goes on a tamed animal, viz. on his own well-tamed self.

title: Dhammapada 23:324
body: The elephant called Dhanapalaka, his temples running with sap, and difficult to hold, does not eat a morsel when bound; the elephant longs for the elephant grove.

title: Dhammapada 23:325
body: If a man becomes fat and a great eater, if he is sleepy and rolls himself about, that fool, like a hog fed on wash, is born again and again.

title: Dhammapada 23:326
body: This mind of mine went formerly wandering about as it liked, as it listed, as it pleased; but I shall now hold it in thoroughly, as the rider who holds the hook holds in the furious elephant.

title: Dhammapada 23:327
body: Be not thoughtless, watch your thoughts! Draw yourself out of the evil way, like an elephant sunk in mud.

title: Dhammapada 23:328
body: If a man find a prudent companion who walks with him, is wise, and lives soberly, he may walk with him, overcoming all dangers, happy, but considerate.

title: Dhammapada 23:330
body: It is better to live alone, there is no companionship with a fool; let a man walk alone, let him commit no sin, with few wishes, like an elephant in the forest.

title: Dhammapada 23:331
body: If an occasion arises, friends are pleasant; enjoyment is pleasant, whatever be the cause; a good work is pleasant in the hour of death; the giving up of all grief is pleasant.

title: Dhammapada 23:332
body: Pleasant in the world is the state of a mother, pleasant the state of a father, pleasant the state of a Samana, pleasant the state of a Brahmana.

title: Dhammapada 23:333
body: Pleasant is virtue lasting to old age, pleasant is a faith firmly rooted; pleasant is attainment of intelligence, pleasant is avoiding of sins. Chapter XXIV. Thirst

title: Dhammapada 24:334
body: The thirst of a thoughtless man grows like a creeper; he runs from life to life, like a monkey seeking fruit in the forest.

title: Dhammapada 24:335
body: Whomsoever this fierce thirst overcomes, full of poison, in this world, his sufferings increase like the abounding Birana grass.

title: Dhammapada 24:337
body: This salutary word I tell you, `Do ye, as many as are here assembled, dig up the root of thirst, as he who wants the sweet-scented Usira root must dig up the Birana grass, that Mara (the tempter) may not crush you again and again, as the stream crushes the reeds.'

title: Dhammapada 24:338
body: As a tree, even though it has been cut down, is firm so long as its root is safe, and grows again, thus, unless the feeders of thirst are destroyed, the pain (of life) will return again and again.

title: Dhammapada 24:339
body: He whose thirst running towards pleasure is exceeding strong in the thirty-six channels, the waves will carry away that misguided man, viz. his desires which are set on passion.

title: Dhammapada 24:340
body: The channels run everywhere, the creeper (of passion) stands sprouting; if you see the creeper springing up, cut its root by means of knowledge.

title: Dhammapada 24:341
body: A creature's pleasures are extravagant and luxurious; sunk in lust and looking for pleasure, men undergo (again and again) birth and decay.

title: Dhammapada 24:342
body: Men, driven on by thirst, run about like a snared hare; held in fetters and bonds, they undergo pain for a long time, again and again.

title: Dhammapada 24:344
body: He who having got rid of the forest (of lust) (i.e. after having reached Nirvana) gives himself over to forest-life (i.e. to lust), and who, when removed from the forest (i.e. from lust), runs to the forest (i.e. to lust), look at that man! though free, he runs into bondage.

title: Dhammapada 24:345
body: Wise people do not call that a strong fetter which is made of iron, wood, or hemp; far stronger is the care for precious stones and rings, for sons and a wife.

title: Dhammapada 24:346
body: That fetter wise people call strong which drags down, yields, but is difficult to undo; after having cut this at last, people leave the world, free from cares, and leaving desires and pleasures behind.

title: Dhammapada 24:347
body: Those who are slaves to passions, run down with the stream (of desires), as a spider runs down the web which he has made himself; when they have cut this, at last, wise people leave the world free from cares, leaving all affection behind.

title: Dhammapada 24:348
body: Give up what is before, give up what is behind, give up what is in the middle, when thou goest to the other shore of existence; if thy mind is altogether free, thou wilt not again enter into birth and decay.

title: Dhammapada 24:349
body: If a man is tossed about by doubts, full of strong passions, and yearning only for what is delightful, his thirst will grow more and more, and he will indeed make his fetters strong.

title: Dhammapada 24:350
body: If a man delights in quieting doubts, and, always reflecting, dwells on what is not delightful (the impurity of the body, &c.), he certainly will remove, nay, he will cut the fetter of Mara.

title: Dhammapada 24:352
body: He who is without thirst and without affection, who understands the words and their interpretation, who knows the order of letters (those which are before and which are after), he has received his last body, he is called the great sage, the great man.

title: Dhammapada 24:353
body: `I have conquered all, I know all, in all conditions of life I am free from taint; I have left all, and through the destruction of thirst I am free; having learnt myself, whom shall I teach?'

title: Dhammapada 24:354
body: The gift of the law exceeds all gifts; the sweetness of the law exceeds all sweetness; the delight in the law exceeds all delights; the extinction of thirst overcomes all pain.

title: Dhammapada 24:355
body: Pleasures destroy the foolish, if they look not for the other shore; the foolish by his thirst for pleasures destroys himself, as if he were his own enemy.

title: Dhammapada 24:356
body: The fields are damaged by weeds, mankind is damaged by passion: therefore a gift bestowed on the passionless brings great reward.

title: Dhammapada 24:357
body: The fields are damaged by weeds, mankind is damaged by hatred: therefore a gift bestowed on those who do not hate brings great reward.

title: Dhammapada 24:359
body: The fields are damaged by weeds, mankind is damaged by lust: therefore a gift bestowed on those who are free from lust brings great reward. Chapter XXV. The Bhikshu (Mendicant)

title: Dhammapada 25:360
body: Restraint in the eye is good, good is restraint in the ear, in the nose restraint is good, good is restraint in the tongue.

title: Dhammapada 25:361
body: In the body restraint is good, good is restraint in speech, in thought restraint is good, good is restraint in all things. A Bhikshu, restrained in all things, is freed from all pain.

title: Dhammapada 25:362
body: He who controls his hand, he who controls his feet, he who controls his speech, he who is well controlled, he who delights inwardly, who is collected, who is solitary and content, him they call Bhikshu.

title: Dhammapada 25:363
body: The Bhikshu who controls his mouth, who speaks wisely and calmly, who teaches the meaning and the law, his word is sweet.

title: Dhammapada 25:364
body: He who dwells in the law, delights in the law, meditates on the law, follows the law, that Bhikshu will never fall away from the true law.

title: Dhammapada 25:366
body: A Bhikshu who, though he receives little, does not despise what he has received, even the gods will praise him, if his life is pure, and if he is not slothful.

title: Dhammapada 25:367
body: He who never identifies himself with name and form, and does not grieve over what is no more, he indeed is called a Bhikshu.

title: Dhammapada 25:368
body: The Bhikshu who acts with kindness, who is calm in the doctrine of Buddha, will reach the quiet place (Nirvana), cessation of natural desires, and happiness.

title: Dhammapada 25:369
body: O Bhikshu, empty this boat! if emptied, it will go quickly; having cut off passion and hatred thou wilt go to Nirvana.

title: Dhammapada 25:370
body: Cut off the five (senses), leave the five, rise above the five. A Bhikshu, who has escaped from the five fetters, he is called Oghatinna, `saved from the flood.'

title: Dhammapada 25:371
body: Meditate, O Bhikshu, and be not heedless! Do not direct thy thought to what gives pleasure that thou mayest not for thy heedlessness have to swallow the iron ball (in hell), and that thou mayest not cry out when burning, `This is pain.'

title: Dhammapada 25:373
body: A Bhikshu who has entered his empty house, and whose mind is tranquil, feels a more than human delight when he sees the law clearly.

title: Dhammapada 25:374
body: As soon as he has considered the origin and destruction of the elements (khandha) of the body, he finds happiness and joy which belong to those who know the immortal (Nirvana).

title: Dhammapada 25:375
body: And this is the beginning here for a wise Bhikshu: watchfulness over the senses, contentedness, restraint under the law; keep noble friends whose life is pure, and who are not slothful.

title: Dhammapada 25:376
body: Let him live in charity, let him be perfect in his duties; then in the fulness of delight he will make an end of suffering.

title: Dhammapada 25:377
body: As the Vassika plant sheds its withered flowers, men should shed passion and hatred, O ye Bhikshus!

title: Dhammapada 25:378
body: The Bhikshu whose body and tongue and mind are quieted, who is collected, and has rejected the baits of the world, he is called quiet.

title: Dhammapada 25:379
body: Rouse thyself by thyself, examine thyself by thyself, thus self-protected and attentive wilt thou live happily, O Bhikshu!

title: Dhammapada 25:381
body: The Bhikshu, full of delight, who is calm in the doctrine of Buddha will reach the quiet place (Nirvana), cessation of natural desires, and happiness.

title: Dhammapada 25:382
body: He who, even as a young Bhikshu, applies himself to the doctrine of Buddha, brightens up this world, like the moon when free from clouds. Chapter XXVI. The Brahmana (Arhat)

title: Dhammapada 26:383
body: Stop the stream valiantly, drive away the desires, O Brahmana! When you have understood the destruction of all that was made, you will understand that which was not made.

title: Dhammapada 26:384
body: If the Brahmana has reached the other shore in both laws (in restraint and contemplation), all bonds vanish from him who has obtained knowledge.

title: Dhammapada 26:385
body: He for whom there is neither this nor that shore, nor both, him, the fearless and unshackled, I call indeed a Brahmana.

title: Dhammapada 26:386
body: He who is thoughtful, blameless, settled, dutiful, without passions, and who has attained the highest end, him I call indeed a Brahmana.

title: Dhammapada 26:388
body: Because a man is rid of evil, therefore he is called Brahmana; because he walks quietly, therefore he is called Samana; because he has sent away his own impurities, therefore he is called Pravragita (Pabbagita, a pilgrim).

title: Dhammapada 26:389
body: No one should attack a Brahmana, but no Brahmana (if attacked) should let himself fly at his aggressor! Woe to him who strikes a Brahmana, more woe to him who flies at his aggressor!

title: Dhammapada 26:390
body: It advantages a Brahmana not a little if he holds his mind back from the pleasures of life; when all wish to injure has vanished, pain will cease.

title: Dhammapada 26:391
body: Him I call indeed a Brahmana who does not offend by body, word, or thought, and is controlled on these three points.

title: Dhammapada 26:392
body: After a man has once understood the law as taught by the Well-awakened (Buddha), let him worship it carefully, as the Brahmana worships the sacrificial fire.

title: Dhammapada 26:393
body: A man does not become a Brahmana by his platted hair, by his family, or by birth; in whom there is truth and righteousness, he is blessed, he is a Brahmana.

title: Dhammapada 26:395
body: The man who wears dirty raiments, who is emaciated and covered with veins, who lives alone in the forest, and meditates, him I call indeed a Brahmana.

title: Dhammapada 26:396
body: I do not call a man a Brahmana because of his origin or of his mother. He is indeed arrogant, and he is wealthy: but the poor, who is free from all attachments, him I call indeed a Brahmana.

title: Dhammapada 26:397
body: Him I call indeed a Brahmana who has cut all fetters, who never trembles, is independent and unshackled.

title: Dhammapada 26:398
body: Him I call indeed a Brahmana who has cut the strap and the thong, the chain with all that pertains to it, who has burst the bar, and is awakened.

title: Dhammapada 26:399
body: Him I call indeed a Brahmana who, though he has committed no offence, endures reproach, bonds, and stripes, who has endurance for his force, and strength for his army.

title: Dhammapada 26:400
body: Him I call indeed a Brahmana who is free from anger, dutiful, virtuous, without appetite, who is subdued, and has received his last body.

title: Dhammapada 26:401
body: Him I call indeed a Brahmana who does not cling to pleasures, like water on a lotus leaf, like a mustard seed on the point of a needle.

title: Dhammapada 26:403
body: Him I call indeed a Brahmana whose knowledge is deep, who possesses wisdom, who knows the right way and the wrong, and has attained the highest end.

title: Dhammapada 26:404
body: Him I call indeed a Brahmana who keeps aloof both from laymen and from mendicants, who frequents no houses, and has but few desires.

title: Dhammapada 26:405
body: Him I call indeed a Brahmana who finds no fault with other beings, whether feeble or strong, and does not kill nor cause slaughter.

title: Dhammapada 26:406
body: Him I call indeed a Brahmana who is tolerant with the intolerant, mild with fault-finders, and free from passion among the passionate.

title: Dhammapada 26:407
body: Him I call indeed a Brahmana from whom anger and hatred, pride and envy have dropt like a mustard seed from the point of a needle.

title: Dhammapada 26:408
body: Him I call indeed a Brahmana who utters true speech, instructive and free from harshness, so that he offend no one.

title: Dhammapada 26:410
body: Him I call indeed a Brahmana who fosters no desires for this world or for the next, has no inclinations, and is unshackled.

title: Dhammapada 26:411
body: Him I call indeed a Brahmana who has no interests, and when he has understood (the truth), does not say How, how? and who has reached the depth of the Immortal.

title: Dhammapada 26:412
body: Him I call indeed a Brahmana who in this world is above good and evil, above the bondage of both, free from grief from sin, and from impurity.

title: Dhammapada 26:413
body: Him I call indeed a Brahmana who is bright like the moon, pure, serene, undisturbed, and in whom all gaiety is extinct.

title: Dhammapada 26:414
body: Him I call indeed a Brahmana who has traversed this miry road, the impassable world and its vanity, who has gone through, and reached the other shore, is thoughtful, guileless, free from doubts, free from attachment, and content.

title: Dhammapada 26:415
body: Him I call indeed a Brahmana who in this world, leaving all desires, travels about without a home, and in whom all concupiscence is extinct.

title: Dhammapada 26:417
body: Him I call indeed a Brahmana who, after leaving all bondage to men, has risen above all bondage to the gods, and is free from all and every bondage.

title: Dhammapada 26:418
body: Him I call indeed a Brahmana who has left what gives pleasure and what gives pain, who is cold, and free from all germs (of renewed life), the hero who has conquered all the worlds.

title: Dhammapada 26:419
body: Him I call indeed a Brahmana who knows the destruction and the return of beings everywhere, who is free from bondage, welfaring (Sugata), and awakened (Buddha).

title: Dhammapada 26:420
body: Him I call indeed a Brahmana whose path the gods do not know, nor spirits (Gandharvas), nor men, whose passions are extinct, and who is an Arhat (venerable).

title: Dhammapada 26:421
body: Him I call indeed a Brahmana who calls nothing his own, whether it be before, behind, or between, who is poor, and free from the love of the world.

title: Dhammapada 26:422
body: Him I call indeed a Brahmana, the manly, the noble, the hero, the great sage, the conqueror, the impassible, the accomplished, the awakened.
